title: Modeling - Logistic Diff Eq with Euler

content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The number of frogs living in a pond at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by the function <math alttext="y equals, uppercase F of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals the fraction 1 over 2500, end fraction, times y, times, open parenthesis, 1010 minus y, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1010</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in weeks. The number of frogs in the pond at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="uppercase F of 0, equals b"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="b"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a positive constant. A slope field for the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals the fraction 1 over 2500, end fraction, times y, times, open parenthesis, 1010 minus y, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1010</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure below. Sketch the solution curve that passes through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 250"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>250</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and sketch the solution curve that passes through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 1500"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1500</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The number of frogs living in a pond at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by the function <math alttext="y equals, uppercase F of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals the fraction 1 over 2500, end fraction, times y, times, open parenthesis, 1010 minus y, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1010</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in weeks. The number of frogs in the pond at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="uppercase F of 0, equals b"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="b"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a positive constant. A slope field for the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals the fraction 1 over 2500, end fraction, times y, times, open parenthesis, 1010 minus y, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2500</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1010</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure below. Sketch the solution curve that passes through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 250"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>250</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and sketch the solution curve that passes through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 1500"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1500</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) If <math alttext="b equals 250"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>250</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the largest rate of increase in the number of frogs in the pond? Explain your reasoning, and indicate units of measure.(ii) If <math alttext="b equals 750"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>750</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the largest rate of increase in the number of frogs in the pond? Explain your reasoning, and indicate units of measure.

Let <math alttext="b equals 100"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate <math alttext="uppercase F of 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the number of frogs in the pond at time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> weeks. Show the work that leads to your answer.

Determine whether the approximation found in part (c) is an underestimate or an overestimate for the number of frogs in the pond at time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> weeks, when <math alttext="b equals 100"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain your reasoning.

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 3.F: Explain the meaning of mathematical solutions in context.
